chapter.title: Task Manager (deprecated)

tip.title: ** The Task Manager is DEPRECATED **
tip.para: In CodeX version 1.7 and above, the Task Manager has been discontinued. It is now replaced by the CodeX Tracker Service (see ). This chapter is included in the CodeX User Guide for projects that originally used the legacy Task Manager.

chapter.para: The CodeX Task Manager can be seen as a light weight project manager. By light weight we mean that it is nowhere near a project management software like CA-SuperProject, MS-Project or other powerful and complex desktop products available on the market. The CodeX Task Manager cannot build a Gantt or Pert chart, it doesn't have any planning capabilities. It is rather a time sheet tool which allows project members to track their time and manage other things like weekly TODO list for instance.
However the CodeX Task Manager offer a number of features that makes it very complementary with the above mentioned project planning tools:

listitem.para: Like all CodeX tools, the Task Manager is entirely web based. Therefore any project member can update his/her time sheet regardless of its physical location.
Tasks can be created and managed by authorized project members.

Each project member has its own time sheet showing all open tasks assigned to her, their priority, description, start and end dates, percentage completion, related tasks, follow-up comments and a full audit trail of the past changes.

Task data can be collected by the project leader(s) at any point in time and exported out of the CodeX project thanks to the Project Data Export facility (see ). This allows for easy generation of progress reports or project re-planning.

chapter.para: As mentioned earlier in this document, the CodeX Bug Tracking system has undergone a number of modifications and enhancements derived from the CodeX users feedback. We expect the CodeX Task Manager to evolve in the same way in the near future. We have as an objective to keep it simple while providing a better integration with other tools that project teams are using for project planning activities. Therefore we value your comments on the way you work and how we could make your life easier with CodeX.

section.title: Task Manager Principles
section.para: Tasks can be created by any project member having the "Tech" level of permission on the Task Manager (see ). A task can be assigned to one or several project members and each of the project members will see the tasks in their own time sheet as soon as assignees are designated.

Tasks are grouped under subprojects. The experience shows that Subprojects generally correspond to high level tasks or modules in the project. Note that, in its current version, the CodeX Task Manager offers a one level only hierarchy where to organize your tasks. In other words, you cannot create a subproject in an subprojects only tasks.

As you already know the general rule in CodeX is that, by default, all information is visible to the CodeX community. This principle also applies to the CodeX Task Manager and by default all your project task are visible to the entire CodeX community. If you want some of your tasks to be visible only to the project members you can create a private subproject and assign the private tasks to it.

tip.title: The CodeX Task Manager is not a project planning tool
tip.para: This is best illustrated by the fact that CodeX does not maintain any kind of dependency between the task fields that are time related. Starts date, end date, percentage complete and total efforts are not inter-dependent. In other words changing any of these values will not cause CodeX to compute new values for the other ones. It is entirely up to the project members to keep the time related fields in sync.

section.title: Task Browsing
section.para: To access the Task Manager of a given project, first go to the Project Summary page (see ) and then select either the "Tasks" item from the Project Main Menu in the upper part of the page or the "Project/Task Manager" item listed the Public Area at the bottom of the Project Summary page.

The welcome screen shows the list of subprojects that have been created in this project (). If a project uses its Task Manager there is at least one subproject listed on the page because any new task must be assigned to a subproject.

figure.title: A Task Manager home page showing 2 subprojects

section.para: Also note that, when more than one subproject have been defined by the project team, a special subproject item called "All tasks in all subprojects" appears at the bottom of the list. This item is generated by CodeX and allows you to access all tasks of all subprojects at once.

By clicking on one of the subproject label you will then be directed to the Task selection and browsing screen () that allows you to better define what set of tasks you are interested in. The Task Manager doesn't have the degree of customizability found in the Bug Tracking System. As a consequence all the screenshots used in this document that have been taken from a particular project on CodeX will look very similar for any other CodeX hosted project.
The Task selection and browsing screen offers a set of 3 criteria to choose from:

listitem.para: Subproject: select the subproject that you want to explore or "Any" if you want the search operation to operate across the entire set of subprojects.

Assignee: select the name of the project member the tasks have been assigned to, "Any" if you want all assignees to be part of the search or "None" to look at the tasks that have not yet been assigned to a project member.

Status: select the status of the tasks you are interested in, "Any" if you want to see all statuses and "None" for tasks that have not be given a status yet (more on the status values and their meaning in ).

figure.title: A sample Task Manager browsing screen

section.para: A click on the "Browse" button initiates the search operation and the matching tasks are displayed in a table format. The task report shows a certain number of tasks fields. Like in the Bug Tracking System, a click on any of the column label will instantly sort the list of tasks according to this criterion. Most of the columns have a straightforward meaning and we'll only focus on those with specific features:

listitem.para: Task ID: this is a unique task ID number. A click on this ID number will show you the task details.
End Date: overdue task have an end date appearing in bold characters. An asterisk (*) on the left hand side of the end date denotes a task that was due more than 30 days ago.
Depend On: shows a list of task ID numbers depending on the task if any. Each task ID number is an hyperlink to the corresponding task details.

section.para: Project members will also find useful shortcuts in the Task Manager menu to quickly access all currently open tasks ("Browse Open Tasks") and also all the tasks they are in charge of ("My Tasks"). The latter is also visible in your Personal Page.

tip.title: Tip: Obtaining nice printouts of task and bug report
tip.para: If you want to print nice reports do not forget to set up the paper orientation to "Landscape" in the print dialog box of your Web browser (File -> Page Setup for IE) to avoid table clipping. Another option to generate more sophisticated printouts is to use the "Project Data Export" facility to instantly download bugs and tasks data in your favorite desktop application like Excel, Word, etc. (see )

section.para: At any time during the search phase, you can toggle the search mode from Simple to Advanced and vice-versa (see the Advanced Search link). The Advance Search mode allows you to select multiple values for each selection criteria. Using this mode you could search for say tasks in "New features" and "Administration - Maintenance" subprojects which status is either open or or suspended.

section.title: Task Submission
section.para: First of all it is worth mentioning that unlike most other CodeX services, new tasks can only be created by project members with appropriate permissions on the Task Manager, not by ordinary registered users. To create a new task in a given project, first go to the Project Summary page (see ) and then select either the "Tasks" item from the Project Main Menu and select the subproject the new task belongs to. Finally click on the "Add Task" item in the Task Manager menu () appearing in the upper part of the screen.
shows the task submission screen from one of the CodeX hosted project (the CodeX project itself actually). Let's review the task fields in order:

listitem.para: Percent complete: goes from "Not Started" to "100%" by step of 5%. This field indicates how much of the task has been completed so far.
Priority: task priority on a scale from 1 (lowest) to 9 (highest)
Task Summary: A one line description of the task

Task Details: a comprehensive description of the task. This field accept formatted text with break lines. Web locations (http://...) typed in the task summary will be automatically transformed into hyperlink when they are later displayed.
Start Date and End Date: calendar days at which the task is expected to start and finish
Assigned To: project members in charge of the task (multiple selection is possible)

Dependent on Task: List of task(s) the new task depends on. Note that the Task Manager does not associate any semantic to the dependency link. It is a very common practice in CodeX to use this dependency relation as a time dependency but it can be any kind of dependency you see relevant for your own project.
Effort (Hours): Initial estimation of the number of working hours required to perform the new task.

section.para: When a new task is created its status is automatically set to Open. This can be changed later in the Task Update screen (see below)

section.title: Task Update
section.para: Once a task has been created a project member with appropriate permissions can update any of the task field to reflect the task progress. Note that ordinary registered users cannot modify a task. They can only view the task details and post a follow-up comment.

To update a task, first use the Task browsing and selection module to retrieve the task you are interested in (remember to use the "My Tasks" shortcut in the Task Manager menu if it's one of your task).

All the screenshots used in this section assumes that the CodeX user is part of the project team. For non project members the screen layout is roughly the same but information shown on the screen cannot be changed.
The Task Update screen is divided in 4 parts: Headers, Comments, Dependencies and History.

section.title: Headers

figure.title: Task Update screen: the Task Headers

section.para: This is where you'll find all the task fields associated with a task description. As shown on , many of these fields (e.g. Status, Subprojects, Priority) are assigned a set of predefined values while some others have a number format (Effort) or a free text format (Task Summary). Most of these fields have already been described in . In this section we'll only focus on the fields that have not yet been explored:

listitem.para: Status: a task status value can be one of

None: this value is normally not used in the CodeX system because all new tasks are automatically set to Open (see below). However it is perfectly ok to use it e.g. for tasks that have not yet been assigned or for pending tasks
Open: this is the status that you should use for all on-going task. This is the default status when a new task is created
Closed: Change the task status to Closed when a task is completed.

Deleted: Use this status for a task that is no longer relevant. Either because the project directions have changed and it doesn't make sense to perform this task or when this task is actually covered by another one. Marking the task as deleted will not delete it for real.
Suspended: the task is on-hold for some time. Use this transient status when you don't want the list of Open tasks cluttered with task that have been delayed by weeks or months.

section.title: Comments
section.para: As many follow-up comments as needed can be attached to any given task. Follow-up comments are free text fields where virtually any kind of information or comment can be typed in. The "Original Comment" field filled out by the task submitter can actually be considered as the first follow-up comment in the life of a task.

For your convenience, the original comment can be modified by using the [Edit] link next to the "Original Comment" field (). We recommend using this feature only to correct typos or add pivotal information overlooked in the initial description. For all other occasions, use the follow-up comments mechanism and do not touch the original description. Follow-up comments allows you to track the history of a task, how the work was done, what source files were impacted, etc.

figure.title: Task Update screen: the Task Follow-up comments

section.title: CC List
section.para: As the CodeX BTS, the Task Manager offers the same powerful email notification system (refer to the BTS for more details ).

section.title: Task Attachments
section.para: In addition to comments, the Task Manager allows you to attach virtually any piece of information to a task in the form of a file. The mechanism is same as the BTS one (see .

section.title: Dependencies
section.para: The next section on the task update screen deals with task-to-task dependencies (see ). CodeX users have the ability to establish a dependency link from a task to one or several other tasks.

The CodeX system does not impose any semantic on the nature of the dependency links between tasks. However it is a common CodeX practice to assume a time dependency between the task displayed on the screen and the selected tasks in the dependency list. In other words, the task in the dependency list must be completed first.

figure.title: Task Update screen: the Task Dependencies

section.para: The task dependency section also gives cross-reference information and shows the list of tasks and bugs that depend on the task you are currently viewing. Refer to for more information about bug-to-tasks dependencies.

section.title: History
section.para: The last part of the task update screen is devoted to task state history (see ). Thanks to this section you can review the entire history of a task. The Task History keeps track of all the changes that occurred on all task fields since the task creation.

The Task History shows what fields changed, what was the old value before the change took place, who changed it and when. Since the Task History only gives you the old value of a bug field it requires a bit of exercise to determine what the new value was right after the change took place.

A Task Change History must be read from top to bottom. Referring to the task headers () you can see that task #12 has its status set to Closed and an effort of 10 hours. Exploring the Task Change History you can say that the status was set to "Closed" on February 9th, 2001 at 11:47am and that the task was "Open" before the change took place. Similarly the effort was updated at the same date and time and went down from 24 hours to 10 hours. You can also infer from the Task Change History that the task priority (currently at 7) was never changed in the life of the task because it doesn't show up in the list. This task was given Priority 7 when it was first created and it never changed after that.

figure.title: Task Update screen: the Task History

section.title: Email Notification
section.para: The Task Manager is equipped with a powerful and flexible e-mail notification system. This system works as the BTS one (see .

section.title: Task Manager Administration
section.para: The Task Manager Administration is available under the item "Admin" in the Task Menu bar. Only project members with Task Administrator permission are allowed to interact with this module.
The Task Administration module gives access to the following administrative functions:

section.title: Add a Subproject
section.para: This is to create a new subproject in the Task Manager. Subprojects generally correspond to high level modules or activities in the project. To create a project you must give it a short subproject name, a one line description and decide whether it is a public or private subprojects. Private Subprojects are only visible to project members.

section.title: Update a Subproject
section.para: Use this function whenever you want to update a subproject. You can change its name and description, whether it is public or private. You can also mark a subproject as deleted. Deleted subprojects will disappear from the Task selection and browsing screen as well as all the tasks that belong to this subproject. At any point in time you can decide to re-activate a deleted subproject without loosing any data.

section.title: Personal Configuration Settings
section.para: This page allows a user to set up personal preferences for the Task Manager. In its current version it allows the user to specify which default date should be displayed in the task submission form for the 'Start Date' and 'End Date' fields. There are two possible choices:

listitem.para: Current Date: if you choose this value, the task creation form displays the current date in both the 'Start Date' and 'End Date' fields. This is the default setting.

No Date: both fields remain empty and the 'Start Date' and 'End Date' are undefined. You may select this option if you use the task manager as a simple TODO list where start and end dates do not really matter.

section.title: Email Notification Settings
Other Configuration Settings
section.para: This module allows you to define the following configuration parameters for the CodeX Bug Tracking System:

listitem.para: An introductory message that displays at the top of the Bug submission form. This is a convenient way to give directions and recommendations to the bug submitter. The text must use HTML tags for formatting which gives a great flexibility to shape the content of this preamble (you can use bold, italic, embedded URL, ...)
Other items may be added in the future.
